extracted_facts.span: Pharmacotherapy, especially selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors antidepressants, remains the most frequent option for treating depression during the acute phase
Depression-focused psychotherapy is the second most common option for helping patients overcome the acute phase, maintain remission, and prevent relapses
Electroconvulsive therapy is the most effective somatic therapy for depression in some specific situations
MAOIs have demonstrated specific efficacy in treating depression with atypical features, such as reactive moods, reverse neuro-vegetative symptoms, and sensitivity to rejection
Trials have demonstrated that MAOIs' efficacy is comparable to that of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)
The use of MAOIs is generally restricted to patients who do not respond to other treatments

TCAs-such as amitriptyline, nortriptyline, protriptyline, imipramine, desipramine, doxepin, and trimipramine-are about as effective as other classes of antidepressants-including SSRIs, SNRIs, and MAOIs-in treating major depression

This efficacy can be explained by the superiority of TCAs over SSRIs for patients with severe major depressive disorder (MDD) symptoms who require hospitalization
In most cases, TCAs should generally be reserved for situations when first-line drug treatments have failed
fluoxetine was as effective as TCAs for treating depression while causing fewer adverse effects
SSRIs have demonstrated comparable efficacy to TCAs and there is no significant evidence indicating the superiority of any other class or agent over SSRIs
SSRIs have demonstrated comparable efficacy to TCAs
studies show no differences in efficacy among individual SSRIs
venlafaxine's efficacy is comparable to that of TCAs
Trazodone has been shown to be an effective antidepressant in placebo-controlled research.

extracted_facts.outcome: efficacy and overall tolerability comparable to SSRIs
extracted_facts.span: Nefazodone's efficacy and overall tolerability are comparable to those of SSRIs, as indicated by comparative trials. However, its use is associated with rare (but fatal) cases of clinical idiosyncratic hepatotoxicity.

extracted_facts.outcome: efficacy comparable to SSRIs in patients with low to moderate levels of anxiety
extracted_facts.span: For individuals with low to moderate levels of anxiety, the efficacy of bupropion in treating MDD is comparable to that of SSRIs.
Bupropion is more likely than some SSRIs to improve symptoms of fatigue and sleepiness.
Vortioxetine have particular benefits in depression-related cognitive impairment.

Trazodone had the highest dropout rates because of their more frequent and severe side effects. Nausea and vomiting were the most common reasons for treatment discontinuation; sexual dysfunction, sedation, priapism, and cardiotoxicity were also reported.

Common adverse effects of ketamine include dizziness, neurotoxicity, cognitive dysfunction, blurred vision, psychosis, dissociation, urological dysfunction, restlessness, headache, nausea, vomiting, and cardiovascular symptoms.

Research on the S-enantiomer of ketamine (S-ketamine, or esketamine, especially intranasal) could also be valuable, as it has a 3 to 4 times greater affinity than ketamine for the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. It was approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration in March 2019 for treatment-resistant depression.

extracted_facts.outcome: Confirmed the role of monoaminergic transmission in depression
extracted_facts.span: Iproniazid confirmed the role of monoaminergic transmission in depression

side_effects: risk of lethal toxicity from overdoses

Psychotherapy for patients with depression strengthens the therapeutic alliance and enables the patient to monitor their mood, improve their functioning, understand their symptoms better, and master the practical tools they need to cope with stressful events.

extracted_facts.condition_name: mild to moderate major depressive disorder
extracted_facts.span: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is recommended for mild to moderate MDD.

extracted_facts.condition_name: mild to moderate major depressive disorder
extracted_facts.span: Interpersonal therapy (IPT) is recommended for mild to moderate MDD.

extracted_facts.drug_name: Cognitive Behavioral Analysis System of Psychotherapy (CBASP)
extracted_facts.span: The European Psychiatric Association recommends using the Cognitive Behavioral Analysis System of Psychotherapy (CBASP) for treating chronic depression.

extracted_facts.outcome: reducing depressive symptoms and preventing relapses
extracted_facts.span: Acceptance and commitment therapy appears to be effective in reducing depressive symptoms and preventing relapses.
Schema therapy is about as effective as CBT for treating depression.

extracted_facts.outcome: clinical course, treatment adherence, and psychosocial functioning
extracted_facts.span: Many studies have highlighted the role of psycho-education in improving the clinical course, treatment adherence, and psychosocial functioning in patients with depression
Brief forms (six to eight sessions) of CBT and PST have already shown their effectiveness for treating depression
ECT is the most well-known treatment for resistant depression, and solid evidence supports its effectiveness and safety.

repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS), vagus nerve stimulation (VNS), deep brain stimulation (DBS), and magnetic seizure therapy, with varying efficiency levels.

ECT is arguably the most effective treatment modality in psychiatry, and its superiority over pharmacotherapy for major unipolar depression is widely supported.
ECT is typically recommended for patients with severe and psychotic depression, a high risk of suicide, or Parkinson's disease, as well as pregnant patients.

Recent literature shows a significant difference between rTMS and fictitious stimulation regarding its improvements in depressive symptoms
Preliminary research has revealed synergistic (e.g., rTMS/quetiapine) interactions between neuro-modulation and pharmacotherapy
Treatments combining rTMS and antidepressants are significantly more effective than placebo conditions, with mild side effects and good acceptability

extracted_facts.condition_name: depressive symptoms in unipolar or bipolar depression
extracted_facts.span: tDCS can be used as a complementary intervention or as monotherapy to reduce depressive symptoms in unipolar or bipolar depression patients
The tDCS technique significantly outperforms the simulator in terms of the rate of response and remission

extracted_facts.effect_size: significant positive outcomes observed after six to 12 mo
extracted_facts.span: VNS has demonstrated progressively increasing improvements in depressive symptoms, with significant positive outcomes observed after six to 12 mo; these benefits can last for up to two years
the results of this study did not indicate that the combination of VNS with typical medical treatments was better than the typical medical treatment on its own

extracted_facts.drug_name: DBS of the subgenual cingulate white matter (Brodmann area = BA 25)
extracted_facts.span: DBS of the subgenual cingulate white matter (Brodmann area = BA 25) elicited a clinical response in 60% of resistant depression patients after six months

extracted_facts.drug_name: DBS of the subgenual cingulate white matter (Brodmann area = BA 25)
extracted_facts.span: DBS of the subgenual cingulate white matter (Brodmann area = BA 25) elicited clinical remission in 35% of patients
ECT is the only somatic treatment with confirmed indications for certain forms of depression.
